clues.text: Alexandra Ripley read this novel 6 times in preparation for writing its sequel, "Scarlett"
She turned her short story collection "Wind and Water" into the bestseller "The Joy Luck Club"
Virginia Woolf originally called her "Mrs. Dalloway" novel this, like a 2002 Nicole Kidman movie
Following up her 1978 bestseller, she dished out "Scruples Two" in '92
"The Senator's Daughter" is one of several thrillers by this daughter of the "Teflon Don"
Shown in 1941, the first TV commercial was a Bulova ad for these
Advertising Age ranked the 1959 "Think Small" ads for this car the top campaign of the 20th century
January 1, 1971 was the last day these could be advertised on U.S. TV
Medieval merchants hired these to shout out praises for their wares in addition to the local news
Clairol's "Does she... or doesn't she" ads read, "Only her mother knows for sure" but were soon changed to this
This well-known fault is considered the main boundary between the North American & Pacific plates
The biggest quake ever recorded, a magnitude 9.5, occurred in 1960 off this South American nation's west coast
S, or secondary, seismic waves travel fairly slowly, but these waves deep in the earth exceed 25,000 mph
The USA's most powerful quake occurred in 1964 in Alaska on this Christian holiday also associated with a quake
A 2005 quake beneath Lake Tanganyika on this 3,500-mile-long "Great" African fault was felt 600 mi. away in Nairobi

rounds.comments: (Alex: Each correct response will be two words joined together.) ... (Alex: Now, a further explanation on the [*].  I said, "two words joined together".  For instance, if we said, "Salt companion & sweat", you would say, "What is pepperspiration?"  That's an example.  So watch out.)

clues.text: Commander-in-chief plus a job with teeth
Tanzanian island of Hope/Crosby fame plus Sweeney Todd profession
Sweet treat symbol of Kojak plus tree of willow family
Hawaiian nut plus an adjective meaning cordial
Amendment to a will plus a Latin American leafy spice, aka coriander
Deadheads know that his ashes were scattered in the Ganges & beneath the Golden Gate Bridge
There's no business like show business, & after her 1984 death, her ashes made a final appearance on Broadway
In 2005 this journalist went out with a bang; his ashes were shot from a cannon near his Colorado home
As requested, his ashes were buried beneath a tree in front of his office on Ventura Blvd. in Tarzana, Calif.
The Boston Public Library houses the ashes & death masks of this anarchist pair executed in 1927
During the 1930s this drought-ridden area of the Great Plains included parts of Kansas, Oklahoma & Texas
In 2001 the Odyssey spacecraft observed one of the largest dust storms ever on this planet
In Genesis "God said unto" this creature "dust shalt thou eat all the days of thy life"
This geographic area is estimated to generate more than 60% of the Earth's airborne dust
In "King Lear", Albany tells her, "You are not worth the dust which the rude wind blows in your face"
In the 1840s he opened a photographic portrait studio on Fulton & Broadway in New York City
Carrie Chapman Catt succeeded this woman as president of the National American Woman Suffrage Association
A flag with a red cross on it flies over her Glen Echo, Maryland home, now a National Historic Site
We tell you no "tails": 19th c. astronomer George Phillips Bond discovered 11 of these celestial bodies
Civil War veteran Ira Dutton became Brother Joseph & helped Father Damien care for the lepers on this island
A Massachusetts cape is named for this state fish, a valuable food source
The largemouth species of this fish is the state fish of Alabama, Florida, Mississippi & Georgia
Called a muskie for short, it's Wisconsin's state fish
This largest species of salmon, Oregon's state fish, shares its name with an Indian tribe & may grow to 3 feet
South Dakota chose the walleye, while North Dakota chose the northern type of this fish
In 1859 Martha Coston patented these devices that sailors could send into the sky to communicate
This device was first developed by Zenith in 1950 under the name "Lazy Bones"
One of the first of these was based on an inclined conveyor belt & used in a NYC elevated train station in 1900
In 1893 this German engineer published "The Theory and Construction of a Rational Heat Engine"
Invented by Philip Drinker in the 1920s, this closed respirator is used by patients who can't breathe on their own
"You Know, Frank's Brother": he "announced that he will write, direct and star in Rocky VI"
This Russian president pocketed a Super Bowl ring being shown to him; Esquire speculated that he pawned it
"Actually, We're Gonna Go With 'Mr. Spears'": "Back then they called me K-Fed, but you can call me Daddy instead", he rapped
"If He's Not Careful, He's Going to Hurt His Reputation": this "Cinderella Man" threw a phone at a hotel worker
"Awkward Moments of the Year": Mike Myers' Hurricane Relief Show appearance with this hip-hopper
I can't believe the ref called one of these on our goalie for elbowing, but I'm ready to go to the box & serve it
Put me in as this substitute on the basepaths!  I'll steal second before you know it
Coach, we need rebounds.  I can lead us to the promised land like this Hall of Fame Rockets & Sixers center
Put me in at quarterback!  Wilson & I have been working on this old-time trick play named for a monument
Put me in at this soccer position also called halfback--I can help on both offense & defense
Many now think that unlike modern reptiles, dinosaurs were homeothermic, meaning this
Edmontosaurus, discovered in this Canadian province in 1917, was almost defenseless & was preyed upon by the T-rex
Despite its great size, this "plated lizard" had a brain the size of a walnut
This city's Carnegie Museum of Natural History has the first Tyrannosaurus rex skeleton, found in 1902
This name of the ferocious predator seen in "Jurassic Park" means "one who seizes quickly"

rounds.text: In the original 1883 work, this title character kills a talking cricket, has his feet burned off & nearly starves
